name.text: Q001 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemThe patient asks the nurse for a bedpan. When the patient is

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

The patient asks the nurse for a bedpan. When the patient is finished, the nurse notices that the patient has bright red streaking of blood in the stool. What is this most likely a result of?

generalfeedback.text: Here is some feedback to test.,

name.text: Q002 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemWhat is currently the most commonly used therapy for peptic

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

What is currently the most commonly used therapy for peptic ulcers?

answer.text: Bismuth salts, antibiotics, and histamine-2 antagonists
Antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, H2 receptor antagonists

name.text: Q003 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemWhat action must always be included in the nursing managemen

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

What action must always be included in the nursing management of a nasogastric tube?

answer.text: Confirm the placement of the nasogastric tube
Have the client sip cool water to stimulate saliva production.
Keep the client in a low Fowler's position.
Connect the tube to continuous wall suction.

name.text: Q004 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemGI intubation may be performed for which of the following re

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

GI intubation may be performed for which of the following reasons? Select all that apply.

answer.text: To obtain a gastric mucosal sample
To aspirate gastric contents for analysis
To test the patency of the pyloric sphincter [CJ2]

name.text: Q005 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemHow should the nurse determine the correct length of a nasog

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

How should the nurse determine the correct length of a nasogastric tube for placement into the stomach?

answer.text: Place distal tip to nose, then ear tip, and then the end of the xiphoid process.
Have the client lie prone and measure tip of nose to umbilical area.
Insert the tube into the nose until tube fills with secretions.
Have the physician order the correct length for insertion.

name.text: Q006 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemA patient presents to the walk-in clinic complaining of vomi

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

A patient presents to the walk-in clinic complaining of vomiting and burning in the mid-epigastria. The nurse knows that to confirm peptic ulcer disease, the physician is likely to order a diagnostic test to detect the presence of what?

name.text: Q007 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemThe nurse is teaching a patient about the impact of smoking

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

The nurse is teaching a patient about the impact of smoking on Gastrointestinal disorders.  The best explanation is:

name.text: Q008 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemA nurse is preparing to discharge a patient after gastric su

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

A nurse is preparing to discharge a patient after gastric surgery. What is an appropriate discharge outcome for this patient?

answer.text: The patient's bowel movements are loose.
The patient eats three meals a day.
The patient maintains or gains weight.
The patient consumes a diet high in calcium.

name.text: Q009 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemThe nurse is completing a health history on a patient whose

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

The nurse is completing a health history on a patient whose diagnosis is chronic gastritis.  Which of the data below should the nurse consider most significantly related to the etiology of the patient's health problem?

answer.text: Consumes one or more protein drinks daily.
Takes over-the-counter antacids frequently throughout the day.
Smokes two packs of cigarettes daily.
Reports a history of social drinking on a weekly basis.

name.text: Q010 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemA patient who experienced a gastric hemorrhage has had the b

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

A patient who experienced a gastric hemorrhage has had the bleeding controlled. The patient's condition is now stable.  The nurse caring for this patient should have as her priority frequent assessment of the patient for what?

answer.text: Coffee ground like  material in nasogastric tube drainage
Irritation of the nares and nasal mucosa

name.text: Q011 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemA patient asks the Home Care Nurse the cause of the distress

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

A patient asks the Home Care Nurse the cause of the distressing symptoms of dumping syndrome. What physiologic occurrence would the nurse explain?

answer.text: Irritation of the phrenic nerve due to diaphragmatic pressure
Chronic malabsorption of iron and vitamins A and C
Reflux of bile into the distal esophagus
Osmotic transport of extracellular fluid into the gastrointestinal tract

name.text: Q012 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemYou are caring for a patient who has a diagnosis of GI bleed

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

You are caring for a patient who has a diagnosis of GI bleed. When you make your shift assessment, you find the patient is experiencing tachycardia and hypotension.  The patient has an episode of hematemesis while you are in the room. What would be a priority nursing action for this patient?

answer.text: Put them in a high Fowler's position.

name.text: Q013 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemWhile caring for a patient hospitalized with chronic gastrit

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

While caring for a patient hospitalized with chronic gastritis it is important to educate the patient about what?

answer.text: The correct use of medications to relieve acute gastritis
How to position themselves to relieve pain

name.text: Q014 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemWhat does the small intestine do? Select all that apply.

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

What does the small intestine do? Select all that apply.

answer.text: Reabsorb water to maintain blood pressure

name.text: Q015 Disorders of the Gastrointestinal SystemA patient presents at the walk-in clinic complaining of stom

questiontext.text:
Disorders of the Gastrointestinal System

A patient presents at the walk-in clinic complaining of stomach pain that is relieved by eating. The nurse suspects an ulcer. How would the nurse explain the acid in the stomach to the patient?

answer.text: Hydrochloric acid is secreted by glands in the stomach in response to the presence or anticipated ingestion of food.
As the stomach digests food it turns part of the digested food into acid.
Our body makes hydrochloric acid for the digestion of the food we eat.
Acid is secreted by cells in the first part of the small intestine, and when we eat, the acid flows into the stomach.

name.text: Q016 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceA patient with anxiety presents to the emergency room. The tri

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

A patient with anxiety presents to the emergency room. The triage nurse notes upon assessment that the patient is hyperventilating. The triage nurse is aware that hyperventilation is the most common cause of which acid-base imbalance?

name.text: Q017 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceYou are an emergency-room nurse caring for a trauma patient. Y

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

You are an emergency-room nurse caring for a trauma patient. Your patient has the following arterial blood gas results: pH 7.26, PaCO2 50, HCO3 28 mEq/L. How would you interpret these results?

name.text: Q018 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceThe nursing instructor is discussing acute respiratory distres

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

The nursing instructor is discussing acute respiratory distress syndrome with her senior nursing class. The instructor states, “A patient in respiratory distress partially loses the ability to regulate changes in pH.” What is the cause of this partial inability?

answer.text: The lungs regulate and reabsorb bicarbonate to change and maintain pH.
The lungs buffer acids through electrolyte changes.
The lungs maintain ventilatory patterns to regulate carbon dioxide levels in the blood to support homeostasis.
The lungs combine carbonic acid and bicarbonate to maintain a stable pH.

name.text: Q019 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceYou are caring for an 82 year old female patient admitted to y

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

You are caring for an 82 year old female patient admitted to your unit 24 hours ago with pneumonia.  She is experiencing dyspnea and has a temperature of 38.5 ℃. What acid-base imbalance would you be concerned that the patient may be at risk for?

name.text: Q020 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceA patient with uncontrolled GERD comes to the ER with abdomina

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

A patient with uncontrolled GERD comes to the ER with abdominal pain. An arterial blood gas (ABG) is drawn. The ABG has the following values: pH = 7.49, PaCO2 = 37 mm Hg, HCO3 = 30 mm Hg. What does the ABG reflect?

name.text: Q021 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceThe nursing instructor is discussing arterial blood gas analys

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

The nursing instructor is discussing arterial blood gas analysis with her senior nursing students. What would she tell her students about the process of compensation?

answer.text: The kidneys retain hydrogen ions and excrete bicarbonate ions to help restore balance.
The kidneys excrete hydrogen ions and conserve bicarbonate ions to help restore balance.
The kidneys react rapidly to compensate for imbalances in the body.
The lungs regulate the bicarbonate level in the intracellular fluid.

name.text: Q022 Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base BalanceYou are the nurse caring for a patient with a history of ulcer

questiontext.text:
Blood Gas Analysis / Acid Base Balance

You are the nurse caring for a patient with a history of ulcerative colitis. The patient is complaining of having abdominal pain and frequent diarrhea for the past week. An ABG reveals the following results: pH 7.28, PaCO2 42 mm Hg, HCO3- 20 mEq/L. What would you know is happening with this patient?
